courses.title: Latin 101 – Beginner Grammar & Vocabulary
courses.description: Latin 101 introduces students to the fundamentals of Latin grammar, vocabulary, and syntax. This course provides a solid foundation for reading and understanding Latin texts through systematic study of grammar, regular vocabulary building, and practice with basic sentences and simple passages.
objectives: Recognize and decline all five noun declensions
Conjugate regular verbs in the present, imperfect, and future tenses
Identify and translate basic sentence structures
Build a core vocabulary of 300+ essential Latin words
Read and translate simple Latin sentences with dictionary assistance
Understand fundamental concepts of case usage in Latin

units.title: Unit 3: Third Declension and More Verbs (Weeks 5-7)
Unit 4: Fourth and Fifth Declensions (Weeks 8-9)
topics: Third and Fourth conjugation verbs (present tense)

units.title: Unit 6: Additional Grammar and Review (Weeks 13-15)
topics: Review and integration of all grammar

courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will learn approximately 300-350 essential Latin words organized by themes:
- Family and relationships
- Home and daily life
- Nature and geography
- Time and numbers
- Basic verbs of action and being
- Common adjectives and prepositions

courses.title: Latin 102 – Intermediate Grammar & Reading
courses.description: Latin 102 builds upon foundational knowledge to introduce more complex grammatical structures and begins the transition to reading authentic Latin texts. Students will master the complete verb system, explore dependent clauses, and develop reading fluency through graded passages from classical authors.
objectives: Conjugate all regular and common irregular verbs in all tenses and moods
Recognize and translate complex sentence structures including subordinate clauses
Use the subjunctive mood in various contexts
Read and translate adapted passages from classical authors
Expand vocabulary to 600+ words
Analyze Latin poetry meter (basic scansion)
Understand indirect statement construction

units.title: Unit 1: Perfect System (Weeks 1-3)
topics: Perfect active tense formation and usage

units.title: Unit 6: Reading Classical Texts (Weeks 13-15)
topics: Review of all grammar and reading techniques

courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand their vocabulary to 600-650 words total, focusing on:
- Military and political terminology
- Abstract concepts and virtues
- Verbs of perception and communication
- Academic and intellectual vocabulary
- Common phrases and idioms
- Historical and geographical terms

courses.title: Latin 103 – Latin Literature & Composition
courses.description: Latin 103 transitions students from learning Latin grammar to using Latin actively. This course combines reading original Latin literature with composition exercises, enabling students to both understand and produce Latin prose. Students will explore diverse genres of Latin literature while developing their own Latin writing skills.
objectives: Read and analyze original Latin texts from multiple genres
Compose original Latin prose using proper syntax and style
Recognize rhetorical devices and literary techniques
Understand historical and cultural contexts of Latin literature
Apply advanced grammatical concepts in both reading and writing
Expand vocabulary to 900+ words
Demonstrate understanding of Latin prose rhythm and style

units.title: Unit 1: Introduction to Latin Prose Style (Weeks 1-2)
Unit 2: Historical Narrative (Weeks 3-5)
topics: Cultural context: Early Roman history and legend

units.title: Unit 3: Philosophical Prose (Weeks 6-7)
topics: Cultural context: Roman philosophy and Stoicism

units.title: Unit 5: Letters and Personal Prose (Weeks 10-11)
topics: Cicero's *Letters to Friends* and *Letters to Atticus*

units.title: Unit 6: Rhetoric and Oratory (Weeks 12-14)
topics: Figures of speech and persuasive techniques
Cultural context: Roman law courts and Senate

units.title: Unit 7: Integration and Final Projects (Week 15)
topics: Comparative analysis of authors and styles

materials: Composition workbook: *Bradley's Arnold Latin Prose Composition* or equivalent
Grammar reference: *Allen and Greenough's New Latin Grammar*
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 900-950 words, emphasizing:
- Literary and rhetorical terminology
- Abstract philosophical concepts
- Historical and political vocabulary
- Stylistic and descriptive words
- Transitional phrases and connectors
- Idiomatic expressions

courses.title: Latin 104 – Advanced Translation & Prose
courses.description: Latin 104 focuses on developing advanced translation skills and deep understanding of sophisticated Latin prose. Students will engage with challenging texts from the Golden Age of Latin literature, mastering complex syntactical structures and stylistic nuances while building expertise in literary translation and textual analysis.
objectives: Translate complex Latin prose with accuracy and elegance
Analyze sophisticated syntactical structures
Recognize and interpret stylistic features of different authors
Understand textual variants and critical apparatus
Produce polished literary translations
Master advanced grammar including rare constructions
Expand vocabulary to 1200+ words
Engage critically with secondary scholarship on Latin texts

units.title: Unit 1: Cicero's Philosophical Works (Weeks 1-3)
topics: Translation workshop: rendering philosophy into English

units.title: Unit 2: Caesar's Commentaries (Weeks 4-5)
topics: Translation workshop: clarity in military narrative

units.title: Unit 3: Sallust's Histories (Weeks 6-7)
topics: Archaic and poetic elements in prose
Translation workshop: capturing Sallust's terse style

units.title: Unit 4: Livy's Historical Narrative (Weeks 8-9)
topics: Pathos and patriotism in historical writing
Translation workshop: balancing drama and accuracy

materials: Oxford Classical Texts or Loeb editions of assigned works
Grammar reference: *Allen and Greenough's New Latin Grammar*
Secondary readings on authors and historical context
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 1200-1300 words, focusing on:
- Philosophical and ethical terminology
- Military strategy and warfare
- Political institutions and processes
- Historical and geographical names
- Stylistic variants and synonyms
- Technical vocabulary from various fields
- Archaic and poetic forms in prose

courses.title: Latin 105 – Roman Poetry & Drama
courses.description: Latin 105 introduces students to the rich tradition of Roman poetry and drama, from early Republican verse to the refined poetry of the Augustan age. Students will study meter, poetic devices, and literary genres while translating works by Rome's greatest poets and playwrights.
objectives: Scan and analyze dactylic hexameter, elegiac couplets, and other meters
Recognize and interpret poetic devices and figures of speech
Translate and analyze poetry from multiple genres
Understand the historical and cultural context of Roman poetry
Appreciate the artistry and literary techniques of Roman poets
Compare different poetic styles and voices
Expand vocabulary to include poetic diction (1000+ words)

units.title: Unit 1: Introduction to Latin Poetry (Weeks 1-2)
topics: Principles of Latin meter and scansion
Introduction to poetic vocabulary and archaisms

units.title: Unit 6: Ovid's Poetry (Weeks 11-12)
topics: *Metamorphoses* (selections: Apollo and Daphne, Pyramus and Thisbe)

units.title: Unit 8: Horace and Lyric Perfection (Week 15)
topics: Sapphic, Alcaic, and other lyric meters
Carpe diem and other Horatian themes
Integration of Greek and Roman traditions

materials: Texts: Oxford Classical Texts or student editions with commentary
Pharr's *Vergil's Aeneid, Books I-VI* or similar
Garrison's *Horace: Epodes and Odes* or similar
Secondary readings on poetic theory and context
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 1000-1100 words, including:
- Poetic and archaic vocabulary
- Mythological names and terms
- Emotional and descriptive language
- Nature and pastoral vocabulary
- Epic formulas and epithets
- Theatrical and dramatic terms
- Synonyms for variety and meter

courses.title: Latin 106 – Roman History Through Texts
courses.description: Latin 106 explores Roman history from the legendary founding of Rome to the fall of the Western Empire through primary source documents and historical texts. Students will read and analyze historical narratives, inscriptions, official documents, and contemporary accounts while developing a deep understanding of Roman civilization, culture, and historiographical methods.
objectives: Read and translate historical Latin texts from various periods
Analyze primary sources critically
Understand Roman historiographical traditions and methods
Identify historical bias and perspective in ancient texts
Place literary works in their historical and cultural context
Read epigraphic and documentary Latin
Expand vocabulary to include historical, political, and administrative terminology (1100+ words)

units.title: Unit 1: Legendary Rome and the Monarchy (Weeks 1-2)
topics: Livy: *Ab Urbe Condita* Book 1 (Romulus, Numa, and the kings)

units.title: Unit 2: The Early Republic (Weeks 3-4)
topics: Livy: *Ab Urbe Condita* Book 2 (establishment of the Republic)
Reading: The Law of the Twelve Tables (selections)
Early Republican institutions: consuls, tribunes, Senate

units.title: Unit 4: The Punic Wars (Weeks 6-7)
topics: Livy: *Ab Urbe Condita* Books 21-22 (Hannibal and Second Punic War)

units.title: Unit 5: Republican Politics and Civil Strife (Weeks 8-9)
Unit 6: The End of the Republic (Weeks 10-11)
topics: Civil wars and the death of the Republic

units.title: Unit 8: Later Empire and Christianity (Week 14)
topics: Vocabulary: Christianity, persecution, late imperial terms

units.title: Unit 9: Review and Historical Synthesis (Week 15)
topics: Using primary sources for historical reconstruction

materials: Reader with inscriptions and documentary sources
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 1100-1200 words, focusing on:
- Political and governmental terms
- Military terminology
- Legal vocabulary
- Administrative language
- Geographical and ethnic names
- Imperial titles and offices
- Religious and ritual terminology
- Social and economic terms

courses.title: Latin 201 – Advanced Syntax & Stylistics
courses.description: Latin 201 provides intensive study of advanced Latin syntax and stylistic analysis. This course examines sophisticated grammatical constructions, rhetorical devices, and stylistic variations across authors and genres. Students will develop mastery of Latin syntax while learning to analyze and appreciate the artistry of Latin prose and poetry.
objectives: Master all complex syntactical constructions in Latin
Analyze stylistic features and rhetorical devices
Distinguish authorial styles and identify characteristic features
Apply advanced grammatical knowledge to translation and composition
Understand historical development of Latin syntax
Recognize and interpret syntactical ambiguities
Produce sophisticated Latin prose with proper style
Expand vocabulary to 1500+ words with nuanced understanding

units.title: Unit 4: Temporal and Causal Expressions (Week 6)
topics: Causal clauses: quod, quia, quoniam, quando

units.title: Unit 5: Comparative and Correlative Syntax (Week 7)
topics: Superlative with quam or genitive partitive

units.title: Unit 7: Rhetorical Figures and Devices (Weeks 10-11)
topics: Figures of speech: metaphor, metonymy, synecdoche
Figures of thought: rhetorical questions, apostrophe
Word order and emphasis: hyperbaton, anaphora, chiasmus

units.title: Unit 8: Stylistic Analysis (Weeks 12-13)
topics: Ciceronian periodic style vs. Sallustian brevitas
Archaic, classical, and Silver Age differences
Readings: Comparative passages from multiple authors

units.title: Unit 9: Advanced Composition (Week 14)
topics: Translating from English to Latin idiomatically

materials: Grammar reference: *Allen and Greenough's New Latin Grammar*
Stylistics handbook: *Latin Prose Composition* by Gildersleeve
Reader with diverse prose and poetry selections
Secondary readings on Latin style and rhetoric
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 1500-1600 words, emphasizing:
- Synonyms and stylistic variants
- Technical grammatical and rhetorical terms
- Rare and poetic vocabulary
- Idiomatic expressions
- Register-specific vocabulary
- Particles and discourse markers
- Philosophical and abstract terminology

courses.title: Latin 202 – Cicero & Classical Oratory
courses.description: Latin 202 offers intensive study of Cicero's oratory and rhetorical theory, along with the broader tradition of Roman public speaking. Students will read complete orations, study Roman rhetorical theory, and understand the cultural and political contexts of classical oratory. This course develops advanced reading skills while exploring one of Rome's most influential literary forms.
objectives: Read and translate complete Ciceronian orations
Analyze rhetorical structure and argumentation
Understand Roman legal and political institutions
Recognize and interpret rhetorical devices
Compare different oratorical styles
Appreciate the cultural significance of Roman oratory
Apply rhetorical theory to textual analysis
Expand vocabulary to 1700+ words including legal and political terminology

units.title: Unit 1: Introduction to Roman Rhetoric (Weeks 1-2)
topics: The five canons of rhetoric: inventio, dispositio, elocutio, memoria, pronuntiatio
Three genres of oratory: judicial, deliberative, epideictic

units.title: Unit 2: Judicial Oratory – Pro Caelio (Weeks 3-4)
topics: The role of ethos, pathos, and logos
Cultural context: Roman sexual morality and politics

units.title: Unit 3: Judicial Oratory – Pro Archia (Week 5)
topics: Defense of a poet: culture and citizenship
The value of literature and learning

units.title: Unit 5: Philippics Against Antony (Weeks 8-9)
topics: Historical context: Civil war and triumvirate

units.title: Unit 7: Rhetorical Theory (Week 11)
topics: Three styles of oratory: plain, middle, grand
Cicero's views on Atticism vs. Asianism

units.title: Unit 8: Other Roman Orators (Weeks 12-13)
topics: Decline of oratory under the Empire

units.title: Unit 9: Performance and Delivery (Week 14)
topics: Ancient sources on delivery and gesture
The social context of Roman oratory

materials: Cicero: *Selected Orations* (Oxford or student editions with commentary)
Secondary readings on Roman rhetoric and politics
Background readings on Roman law and politics
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 1700-1800 words, focusing on:
- Legal terminology (ius, lex, reus, iudex, etc.)
- Political vocabulary (consul, senatus, populus, etc.)
- Rhetorical technical terms
- Philosophical vocabulary
- Emotional and ethical language
- Idiomatic expressions
- Stylistic variants and synonyms
- Historical and cultural references

courses.title: Latin 203 – Virgil & Epic Literature
courses.description: Latin 203 provides intensive study of Virgil's *Aeneid* and the Roman epic tradition. Students will read substantial portions of the *Aeneid* in Latin, developing mastery of dactylic hexameter while exploring epic conventions, Virgilian style, and the cultural significance of Rome's national epic. The course also examines Virgil's influence and the broader context of Latin epic poetry.
objectives: Read and scan dactylic hexameter fluently
Translate and analyze extensive passages from the *Aeneid*
Recognize and interpret epic conventions and devices
Understand Virgilian style and poetic techniques
Appreciate the political and cultural context of the *Aeneid*
Compare Virgil with Homer and other epic poets
Identify intertextual allusions and literary influence
Expand vocabulary to 1600+ words including epic diction

units.title: Unit 1: Introduction to Epic and Virgil (Weeks 1-2)
Unit 2: Aeneid Book 1 – Arrival in Carthage (Weeks 3-4)
Unit 3: Aeneid Book 2 – The Fall of Troy (Weeks 5-6)
topics: The Trojan Horse and city's destruction

units.title: Unit 4: Aeneid Book 4 – Dido and Aeneas (Weeks 7-8)
Unit 6: The Italian Books (Week 11)
topics: *Aeneid* Book 8 (selections): Evander and the site of Rome

units.title: Unit 9: Epic Tradition and Influence (Week 14)
topics: Later Latin epic: Lucan, Statius, Silius Italicus

units.title: Unit 10: Synthesis and Final Projects (Week 15)
topics: Major themes: fate, pietas, Rome's destiny

materials: Virgil: *Aeneid* (Oxford Classical Text or Pharr's edition)
Commentary: Servius, Williams, or modern scholarly commentary
Secondary readings on Virgil and epic
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 1600-1700 words, including:
- Epic vocabulary and archaic forms
- Poetic synonyms (mare/aequor, etc.)
- Military terminology
- Mythological names and epithets
- Geographical terms
- Religious and ritual vocabulary
- Emotional and psychological terms
- Nautical language
- Epic formulas and stock phrases

courses.title: Latin 204 – Latin for Scholars (Advanced Translation)
courses.prerequisites: Latin 201 and at least one 200-level Latin course
courses.description: Latin 204 is designed for advanced students pursuing scholarly work in classics, history, philosophy, or related fields. This course develops professional-level translation skills, introduces scholarly tools and methods, and provides experience with diverse types of Latin texts from antiquity through the Renaissance. Students will work with both literary and non-literary sources, developing the comprehensive skills needed for independent research.
objectives: Translate complex Latin texts from any period with scholarly precision
Use scholarly apparatus including critical editions and commentaries
Read and interpret Medieval and Renaissance Latin
Work with epigraphic, papyrological, and manuscript sources
Apply paleographic knowledge to manuscript reading
Conduct independent research using Latin sources
Evaluate and compare published translations
Expand vocabulary to 2000+ words across diverse registers and periods

units.title: Unit 1: Scholarly Tools and Methods (Weeks 1-2)
topics: Introduction to critical editions and apparatus criticus
Using commentaries, lexicons, and scholarly resources
Oxford Classical Texts, Teubner, and Loeb editions
Digital resources: Perseus, PHI Latin Texts, Thesaurus Linguae Latinae

units.title: Unit 2: Classical Prose – Philosophical Texts (Weeks 3-4)
topics: Secondary reading: Modern scholarship on Roman philosophy

units.title: Unit 4: Medieval Latin Texts (Weeks 6-7)
topics: Early Medieval Latin: Gregory of Tours, Bede (selections)

units.title: Unit 5: Legal and Administrative Latin (Week 8)
topics: Context and interpretation of legal sources
Using legal dictionaries and reference works

units.title: Unit 6: Renaissance Humanist Latin (Weeks 9-10)
topics: Neo-Latin poetry: George Buchanan or others

units.title: Unit 9: Sight Translation and Unseen Passages (Week 13)
topics: Common pitfalls and how to avoid them

units.title: Unit 10: Independent Research Projects (Weeks 14-15)
topics: Students present research using primary Latin sources
Translation and commentary on chosen text
Discussion of scholarly methods and findings

materials: Medieval Latin dictionary (Niermeyer or Du Cange)
Access to digital databases (Perseus, PHI, etc.)
courses.vocabularyGoals:
Students will expand vocabulary to 2000+ words, including:
- Complete classical core vocabulary
- Medieval Latin vocabulary
- Christian and ecclesiastical terms
- Legal and administrative language
- Technical and scientific terminology
- Renaissance humanist vocabulary
- Regional and temporal variations
- Abbreviations and formulaic expressions
